ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would strongly recommend this course to other students.

The course begins with the question of persistence. What does it mean for a thing to persist from t1 to t2?This question is answered by two divergent positions in contemporary debates. Perdurantism considers time as a determining factor in that each moment corresponds to a metaphysical part of a larger whole that exists across time. Endurantism considers the identity of a thing as wholly present at each moment in time.But there are problems. Either things are scattered parts that cannot add up into wholes, or there is no reasoned explanation for how one thing continues onto being itself at another point in time.The divergent opinions are locked in an impasse.Why?Perhaps we are asking the wrong question.The problem is that we cannot resolve the fact of individuated things. This is a question of relations.We climb a steep mountain. This is the Parmenidean Ascent. The air is cold up there...and few are around to keep us company (or at least they don't know that they are keeping us company in eternal solidarity).We write our papers to console ourselves (or out of joy).
Yes, I would recommend this course.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: This course deepened my knowledge of my discipline, because it covered in a systematic way some of the most fundamental issues in metaphysics, philosophy of action, and epistemology. It has also helped shape my approach to philosophical problems more generally.
